reviews.review_text: What's the first thing that comes to mind, when reviewing a video game? Well, for me, it has to be the visual world that captures the core of our imaginations. And with this little gem called Half-Life, it comes as no exception that this game continues to boggle the mind and leave gamers alike wondering. There is more heart, creativity and scientific ingenuity there is in this one title than there is in most series and is arguably Valve's greatest achievement. With over 50 game awards, it's a strong justification. Half-Life isn't just one of the greatest FPS' games of all time. Half-Life isn't literally one of the best purchases you can ever get on Steam. Half-Life is quite simply, one of the greatest games ever made.  When compared to certain FPS' games in the past and todays time, which both heavily rely on long-winded cutscenes to present the main narrative of the game, Half-Life annihilates this often compulsed aspect, by detailing the plotlines that keeps the player still in control of the first-person viewpoint, leaving the cutscenes rolling while you still have full access to the gameplay and character controllability. For summarization, You will see through the eyes of Gordon Freeman at all times.  The game is a perpetual maze; leaving the player to work at tasks that involve being locked into battle and overall puzzle solving to advance through the many challenges that wait up ahead. Most of the time, the story illuminates the puzzles by the actions to proceed, such as maze scenarios and building boxes to use as staircases. Although Half-Life has short-lived loading screens from time to time after leaving a certain area for a new one, the game has no levels. But, to make up for this traditional concept, the game is split into a number of mind-boggling chapters filled with rich story and easy adaptability.  To start off with this game's story, you're none other than Gordon Freeman. A young man who holds a Ph.D in theoretical physics who starts his daily grind back at the Black Mesa Research Facility; a fictional complex that is stranded in a remote desert located in the suburbs of New Mexico. Arriving late for work yet again, you take the tram system around the Black Mesa Research Facility and at this point, objectives that his game has fulfilled such as breath-taking visuals and movie quality animation begins to blossom. The tram sequence at the beginning of the game can only be summed up in one word; Incredible. It's as if the things that come flying at you from every angle and position, almost reminiscent of watching an action-packed movie, along with the credits of the producer's names proudly fading in and out on the corner of the screen.  As you make your first step in the heavily secured facility, you're constantly reminded that you put on your Hazardous Environmental suit, or the H.E.V suit for short. While all things are hunky-dory, those things soon turn to the worst very soon. After a failed experiment, involving a collision between a rare intergalactic specimen from another dimension with an Anti-Mass Spectrometer, the Black Mesa facility falls in ruins, meaning you are one of the only key survivors of the infamous ''Black Mesa Incident''. And with this, alien life-forms from the dimension of ''Xen'' are pulled from their dimension into ours and are running amok the ruined facility, along with the Army that storm the place after the gone, haywired facility's emergency call has been echoed. This of course doesn't make things any easier and you soon find yourself battling both the aliens and the military.  While there isn't exactly much to complain about, I would admit that guiding the chickened-out scientists and professors around the facility can be quite a pain now and again due to some seldom poor AI programming, as well as the alien life-form, Vortigaunt, from which you would have to wait and be patient for them to wreck down wooden doors in front of you, as you are not capable of doing that yourself. (You do start off with a crowbar, right?) As well as I'm probably not the only one who made the same mistake by killing them through a small opening, before they did in fact begin to tear down the doors. But then again, this is where the used scripted intermissions started to show, so that's an added bonus to the magnitude of the game.  For the long run, I've had fun and joy both reviewing this amazing game and playing this amazing game. If you haven't play Half-Life or even worse, not familiar with Half-Life, it's still a big compulsory recommendation from me.

Maybe Black Mesa... or how Gordon Freeman changed the world - a must-have, if you're not a graphic next-gen purist.  During an experiment gone wrong, where you're the one that pushed the crystal into the analyzer, you're the only hope of the survivors to reach the search and rescue team, because of your combinaison. However, you'll have to survive from the attacks of your coworkers transformed in zombies and creatures coming from another world. And unfortunately for you, your only weapon is a crowbar. And you're just a scientist employed by Black Mesa...  That's Half-Life for you. A scientist relying on a crowbar first before becoming an expert in weapons. The story is perhaps basic and with some twists but noneless, the universe build around Half-Life has expanded a lot.  However, if Half-Life is a FPS, which means weapons to shoot any enemies, that you can carry thanks to your wonderful combinaison, you can find some puzzles throughout the game, mainly because of the need to wander around a destroyed facility.  What's fascinating in Half-Life isn't probably the gameplay in itself. I mean, everything seems very basic. But if it wasn't for it, you wouldn't have mods like Counter-Strike around. I don't know why I was fascinated by Half-Life. I mean, it's not like jumping was new or that weapons were innovative... maybe the iconic crowbar has to do something with. Or maybe it's just that a plot, perhaps basic but very effective, the mysterious G-Man following you around and disappearing easily or that the fact it's someone that wasn't trained to become the hero of the world... or maybe the ending. I don't know but I just know that when I played it, I was fascinated.  I was fascinated by the fact that you can find survivors around that can help you, guards or scientists. Or the fact that some of them meet a tragic fate under your eyes. I was fascinated by the change of the objectives: from reaching the surface, you're now the only hope to end an invasion and the wiping of any survivor by the soldiers.  I don't remember any problem with the gameplay apart the treacherous ladders. Climbing them isn't hard. However, when you needed to step out of them OR going down, it was a challenge. And the famous jumping with the crates where you were sliding...  Half-Life has the graphics from 1998 and it was very good ones. Even now, I could still enjoy them. I don't say that it's detailed. But you can see some interesting details. And Xen, the other world, despite being a challenge, is very beautiful.  Besides, the soundtrack is also great. It's only heard during some important moments. But the music is powerful.  Half-Life is a classic to have. Gordon Freeman is a character that you can't forget.

Half-Life is my old love so I found this review kind of hard to put together, since I had to put aside my nostalgia and deliberate precisely on what makes Half-Life an excellent game, but here goes my best.  Half-Life is seemingly a classic FPS however back when It was released it was anything BUT, Half-Life was a frigging revolutionary game that defied FPS standards while still preserving what makes FPS fun and good. And Half-Life IS fun, Its got a wide and diverse range of weapons and enemies (as well as some cool bosses) and some brilliant AI that still impresses me today.  But what really makes Half-Life a really stand out game is what it does that is different. Rather then going the way of a metal gear solid game valve opted for a really interesting minimal storytelling approach in which everything is witnessed through the gameplay, there are no cutscenes of any kind. The less is more approach works and instead of long pieces of poorly written dialogue the game lets you observe first hand the chaos and destruction in the aftermath of the Black Mesa Incident. It works and the atmosphere feels like the aftermath of some kind of horrible and ongoing disaster like a huricane or a Nuclear blast In which you must fight for your life throughout the game to escape.  Rather than explain everything to you Half-Life will show you a lot of things or occasionaly say things that may confuse you. This is because you are just one man and its impossible for you to comprehend the big picture, you are small and insignificant in this grand scheme going on and while you get vague hints throughout the game as to this bigger picture the game leaves you guessing which gives the game a large sense of a forboding and sinister mystery .  This game is built on atmosphere and while the graphics have aged a lot, it is still a breath taking experiance to witness the disaster and destruction of Black Mesa. The sounds and music are top notch and aid with this of course.  If you are one of the few people who has not played Half-Life yet I really suggest that you get around to it, you wont just have fun but I think It will probably influence your opinion on how Video Game stories and atmosphere should be handled in relation to gameplay.

This is the FPS. Half-Life MADE the FPS type of game. For the 90s, it was very different. You werem't shot into a base on Mars, fighting every demon under the sun. You were a normal scientist who was at the wrong place at the wrong time. You, Gordon Freeman, must fight your way through a alien-infested under ground base called Black Mesa. Sounds boring, well its not. The wide range of aliens to fight and their amazing A.I will scare you!  As for the FPS portion, its also great. You see everything from the eyes of Gordon Freeman. There is a reason you can take a lot of damage and why there is a HUD, your Hazardous Enviroment Vest (H.E.V) or better known as the H.E.V suit, protects you from a wide range of dangers. To freezing cold chambers to electricity-shooting aliens, it protects you. Giving a reason why you can take so much.  The weapons are great! They're placed very well. You find the shotgun in a little base wich makes sence, you find the glock next to the dead body of a guard, etc... Also the ammo changes too! Depending on wich part of the base you are, the will be more or less of a ammo type, forcing you to use all your weapons in order to survive.  As for the story, it makes so real sence...but its great. A huge amount of mass builds up, creating a portal between Earth and the border world, ZEN were aliens have been hiding from the Combine (as seen in Half-Life 2). They flee to Earth hence why the base is over run with aliens. The militery come to kill the aliens...and the survivors. Its a goverment cover-up and you're Black Mesa's best hope of cleaning the base of all aliens and soldiers.  Over all: Buy it, you won't regret it...

Half life 1, well were to begin, everybody and their long lost relatives know what half life is and they also know how much it raised the 'FPS' genre onto its feet and pushed the bar high. A lot of modern day shooters fail to provide the atmosphere and the fluid simple controls of this great title, There have been so many people reviewing this game so I'm finding it quite hard to start so i guess i shall start by telling you what the game is about.  -----SPOILERS---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Dr. Gordon Freeman arrives late for work at 8:47 am in the Black Mesa Research Facility, using the advanced Black Mesa tram system that leads through the facility. He arrives at the Anomalous Materials Lab, his work place, and he is informed by the security officer that the scientists have a special experiment today, so he goes to the locker room and puts on the hazard suit. He goes to the lab's lower levels, and arrives at the Anti-Mass Chamber, where he is instructed that the specimen to be used that day is the rarest and also the most unstable specimen the lab has ever worked with. He is tasked with pushing the specimen into the scanning beam of the Anti-Mass Spectrometer for analysis. However as soon as he pushes it, it explodes, and creates a sudden catastrophe called a 'resonance cascade'  -----SPOILERS----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  The story is really good, its actually quite funny, modern games often spend massive amounts of money on spectacular scenes and explosions and deep heart felt commentary in order to set the mood......But How does half life do it that right with a 8-10 minute opening 'TRAM RIDE' into the Black Mesa facility, and all it really is, is Mr. freeman going into work that day, and that scene alone provides one of the most enigmatic experiences i have ever felt in the prologue of a game.  players enlist the help of traumatized scientists and trigger-happy security guards to get through high-security zones, sneaking and fighting your way through ruined missile silos and Cold War cafeterias, through darkened airducts and subterranean railways. When you finally come in sight of the surface, you realize that the inhuman monsters aren't your only enemies-for the government has sent in ruthless troops and stealthy assassins. Their orders seem to be that when it comes to the Black Mesa, nothing gets out alive... and especially not you.   That said the journy would be nothing without great enemys with complex ways to kill them like the headcrabs, and nothing would kill them better than the coverted crowbar that 'Freeman' Wields. The weapons apart from that are nothing special, exept maybe the laser designated RPG launch  There are no levels in Half-Life, or, more specifically, it lacks the concept of levels and episodes we've come to expect. The game is a continual stream of locations from beginning to end. You can move back and forth at will (with only a few exceptions), as can those who are pursuing you. And though the brief loading time between zones is the one artifact that breaks the flow of the game, the transitions are thankfully brief.  Weapon, ammunition, and health placement follows the same philosophy. You'll hardly ever come across an item that is just bobbing and spinning in place like some gift from the heavens. Valve has done a good job of justifying the typical health and armor meters. Freeman is wearing a hazard suit, used by researchers involved in dangerous experiments. To regain health and armor energy, you must fill up at power stations. These are almost always located in logical places, usually near areas where dangerous work would be performed. There are no power-ups to be found. Weapons and ammo are taken from supply closets or the corpses of fallen security guards and soldiers. Even the more experimental weapons have their proper place - in the weapons research department of the facility. And late in the game, once you've left the research facility, the supply of ammo and first aid kits is believably scarce.  The only problems with Half-Life are the results of it being so ambitious. The fact that all of the humans in the game look like clones takes from the otherwise realistic atmosphere. The diversity of the levels and puzzles will undoubtedly leave you thinking some areas were better than others. But complaints that arise are simply a reaction to the fact that the game is so close to ideal. Half-Life is an exceptional single-player game and a solid multiplayer game.  ---------------------------------------- 10/10 - masterpiece

After an experiment went  HORRIBLY  wrong, Freeman must now fight his way through the enormous compunds of Black Mesa to survive. Later he is told that soldiers have arrived to rescue them, but is it really so?  Gameplay: The gameplay is fun and interesting, and was at the time different from most First-person shooters. Half-Life focused less on the guns and required more thinking to succed. This is a great thing. The guns are still there, and most of them are fun to use, like the Shotgun and Pistol. Overall, the gameplay is superb, and holds up well even today.  Music: The music is great, and fits the game perfectly. Some of the music feels creepy, like 'Space Ocean' which plays after the disastrous experiment, and other pieces get you pumped, like 'Drums and Riffs' which plays after you launch a rocket at a later part in the game.  Overall, Half-Life was great back 1998 when it came out, and is still great even to this day. Pick it up if you got the chance, you will by no means regret it. Admittedly I could've worded my last review better. Half-Life is a classic, but it's not one that holds up that much. It hasn't aged well, I'm trying to say. And I have plenty of reasons why.   -LEVEL DESIGN-  Atmospherically, Half-Life 1 is amazing. Really. The idea of a scientific complex falling into chaos all around you as you desperately try to escape is executed really well, and it's one of the most atmospheric games of its time. That's where my positive points end. In terms of level design itself, Half-Life 1 is bad. Really bad. There's no map system which is inexcusable in a game so labryinthine. On top of that, a lot of the levels can get cryptic and annoying, some are nearly impossible if you don't have enough health. Like the dam in Surface Tension, where you have to dodge both a fish monster and helicoptor fire while also standing in place opening a valve for just long enough to start drowning. I've hit roadblocks throughout the whole game, barely going 15 minutes without hitting a dead end and being stuck for twice that time. At least, that's my experience. Black Mesa does everything so much better. It's really the best version of HL1. If you want a better experience with this game, go get that. Who cares about Xen?   -Gameplay-  Half-Life's actual gameplay is its strong point. It has lots of unique weapons, all of which are really fun to use. Like, really. There are a LOT of weapons. They're all really cool. Other than that, it's okay. I really don't think I have to describe HALF-LIFE'S gameplay to you.   Especially considering you most likely filtered reviews to 'Negative' looking for something to be mad about.   But I do like the gameplay. However, as the levels went on, I started noticing a trend in my playstyle. I would just run past all the enemies, speedrunner-style. I don't really know why. Maybe it was the level design making fights unrewarding. Maybe I just wanted to beat the game to get it over with. But the most likely conclusion is that fighting enemies in HL1 is very unrewarding. In most cases you end up taking more damage by fighting than if you just dash through the area. And as mentioned, the level design doesn't help either. Nearly every enemy uses hitscan and sometimes you're pitted up against nearly 8 of them at once in a singe room.   -Rapid-fire of the smaller bits-   Music:  The game uses music very sparingly. If there's a song, it'll only play once at a key point of the game. So most of the game is quite silent. That's okay, I guess. I don't like silent games, but It's just an excuse to use my own music. The songs it does play are pretty good, though.  Story:  Easily the best part of the game. I already mentioned how much I like the atmosphere, but the story is pretty good. That's all I'll say.  Is it fun?:  Kinda. Things go pretty well until you hit a killjoy roadblock. Something I really like about the game, though, is how small the hitboxes on projectiles are. You can hit someone through the tiniest crack in a wall with a crossbow without the bolt stopping in mid-air on the surrounding walls. If you can see the enemy, you can hit them. Can that be said for many other games? Refer to Level Design for my thoughts on the killjoys.   -Overall-  Look, I get it. Half-Life 1 is a decent game. But it's not a masterpiece. It has a lot of flaws, and I generally didn't enjoy playing this. I really want to like the game, because it's HALF-LIFE. But too much of the game design frustrated me to the point of never wanting to play it again. I did beat the game. But it felt like a chore more than anything. I didn't enjoy Xen at all. Who does? Really though, if you want to play through the best version of Half-Life, go get Black Mesa. It fixes EVERYTHING this game does wrong, and improves on it. If you want a better first-party Half-Life experience, get HL2. It's way more fun in every way and has its own unique set of weapons. Overall, Half-Life 1: Good gameplay, ruined by awful level design. That being said though, it is quite moddable. Give the community creations a shot sometime, and you may like it better.  6/10

I mean, sure you could just ignore the scientist and fly right through the game but then you would miss out on the extraordinary experience which is really what Half-Life is all about (and be completly lost and confused by the end of it aswell)... Half-Life has a great beginning even though it is a little boring but I loved that first 20 minutes of strolling through the office and talking to you're co-scientist because it gets you involved with the game.... Half-Life has great narrative pacing which you just don't see in games anymore today..... I also loved Half-Life because the enviroments are so detailed... I have played Half-Life three times already and I still keep finding new room's and compartments in Black Mesa that have ammo and health packs in them.... The game, the legend, the one that put Valve on the map.  The release of Black Mesa on Early Access inspired me to play the original game and the fact that I started first with Half-Life 2 and wanted more, which coincidentally I can compare the two on their merits.  To keep this out of the way, Half-Life may be old by now, but it has dated very well in many terms. The graphics are old, but very impressive for their time, it's quite smooth, the shooting works great and the unbroken first-person gameplay is still great as it is today. It may not be so important now considering that game like Bioshock, Far Cry 3 and this games own sequel got ahold of the method, but not many can do it as well as the original Half-Life and it still engages you into the game and makes for an excellent narrative method. Much like the sequel, the game despite being a shooter, also includes variety in plataforming, exploring and navigation that make the game varied and avoids getting stale as you continue.  Now, although I really liked this game, there are several things that hold it back from being a favorite of mine. Now, I don't know if it's the difficulty level (I played in normal throughout), but some of the enemies have a bad case of bullet sponge, which can be quite annoying. Another things would be the fact that despite the cool soundtrack and its greatness when it's used in battles and certain moods, there's not a lot of music throughout. Finally of course, there's Xen, which while I certainly thought it had great ideas, wasn't a very inspiring last level and the last boss battle can feel a bit anticlimatic, partly due to the teleporting breaking you into different areas and not keeping any momentum and also a lack of music and epic tone that tells 'This is it, time to show who is the boss!'. At the very least the last scenes were very intriguing and do a nice ending.  I guess another thing would be that what the first game did great, the second game did a lot better in every department, including and actually awesome final level and a better immersion for the player, which doesn't mean that the first game can't be awesome on its own right, but feels a bit overshadowed compared to the sequel and dated in some respects.  Despite all that I said, I still had a great time with Half-Life and I do consider it a masterpiece for its time. It's definitely influenced many things that gaming would adopt and really showed what PC gaming was capable of.

Reviewing a 15 year old game is really challenging, considering the fact that everything about gaming has changed ever since, BUT if I say that this 15 year old game is what single handedly paved the way for what shooters are today its bold statement. HALF-LIFE needs no introduction, out in 1998 it had a very powerful impact in the industry, back in a time when FPS was all about running and gunning through narrow corridors HALF-LIFE single handedly changed that trend, it was a revolution of its time and was a direction for game developers.  The story is very simple, you are a scientist who works for a top secret research facility, one day an experiment goes horribly wrong and it rips open a portal to another dimension, the base is riddled with alien life forms and in order to confront the situation the govt. dispatches soldiers, their mission is not only to wipe out the threat but also the evidence which includes the entire Black Mesa science team including you, it’s all about survival. Simple story but the game has a very powerful sense of narration, story-telling and presentation.   Its crafted so well that it stands the test of time even today, the ones who played this game when it was released know why HALF-LIFE is praised so much, the ones who play it today find it stale, I don’t blame them but fact is that this was the first game to implement narration and ingame story telling without the player leaving control, no cut scenes or anything that takes you away from the player, even levels have a cohesive transition, they are merged by loading screens so the game feels like a smooth flow. Games today lack that kind of flow. The premise of the game is so well designed it feels like a living breathing world with an ecosystem.   It’s the game that merges old school shooters with new or lets just say it brings shooters to a whole new direction. there is a wide variety of weapons at your disposal, each one of them behaves so perfect that shooting is very satisfactory, also there is a wide variety of foes who have different behavior, today these things are very common but imagine all of these things in 1998, it bagged more than 60 GOTY awards.   The level design, the sound design, the atmosphere, the feel of claustrophobe and isolation, the desperation of survival are some of the attributes that make HALF-LIFE.  If there was no HALF-LIFE, there wouldn’t have been VALVE, this is the game that made them, gave them this legendary stature.   For the love of gaming play this. You owe it to yourself.

A normal day turned into a nightmare. A normal man turned into a hero. Valve Software's (Presently, Valve Corporation's), 1998 game, Half-Life, is a masterpiece of gaming that never lets up from start to finish. A masterfully, perfect balance of storyline, pacing, action and atmosphere, don't pass this one up! The premise of the story, sees its protagonist, Seattle, Washington, native, Gordan Freeman, a graduate of MIT and having a Ph.D in theoretical physics on his first day of work at an undisclosed location in the New Mexican desert, known as the Black Mesa Research Facility. On a normal day of work, (wouldn't you know that it had to happen on his first day) devastation ensues when a science experiment goes horribly wrong by his own hand or at least partly by his own hand. He doesn't really know what's going on because everything has happened so very quickly, but all he knows is that he must rise to the occasion. He must take on a sense of responsibility for his own actions and attempt to escape the Black Mesa Research Facility, alive, all the while fighting off dimensional aliens and the military forces that have been sent in to clean up the evidence (mess lol). He also enounters the mysterious, G-Man, along the way. A mysterious and eerie figure with a suit and briefcase. One can only assume that Gordon Freeman, because of being a silent character, is constantly questioning what is going on as a result of his actions. He doesn't know but he does it, anyway. Quite the hero! When the player gets to the end of the game, he finds that there's time for only a bit of relief and none for celebration of actually being able escape the facility and Xen, alive, as the mysterious G-Man offers to either hire on Freeman or offer him 'an anticlimax'. There's also quite a bit to say about the G-Man but very little at the same time. Whether the G-Man is a person, some sort of an entity or a figment of the imagination brought on by some sort of attempted mind control or experiments (possibly, government-owned), is not, yet, known. Perhaps, the in-game character of G-Man could even be a reflection of his real life counterpart. On the topic of the soundtrack. The entire soundtrack was brilliant and fit extremely well into the entire atmosphere and storyline of the game. My favorite OST from the Half-Life Original Soundtrack, was Sirens in the Distance. Sirens in the Distance encompassed a sense of eerieness, mystery, perseverance, and was a firm reminder that an average person turned hero now has a sense of duty to take responsibility for his own actions, to not only fight for his own survival but little does he know at the time, the fate of the world as well. The OST begins with hearing the sirens blare twice, over and then the music begins to mimic the sirens and it seems to kind of merge with them at the same time, which was a very creative, move. To me, this OST marks the beginning when his present predictament finally sinks in to Gordon and he really begins to wonder if his actions may not be contained solely within the confines of the facility, itself but may have spread to the outside, world as well. What's happening out there? Is it the same that's happening in, here? Could it be worse? These are imporant questions for when we get to the second game, Valve's Half-Life 2 (2004), things start to be brought into a perspective a bit clearer than, before. We now know that the disaster has made a significant spread into the world, outside of the Black Mesa Research Facility, that the predicatament is worse than originally, thought. The brilliantly developed, protagonist, Gordon Freeman is the single greatest video game character in history. What I really love about Gordon Freeman, above all the other traits, is that the player knows quite a bit about him but also really nothing at the same time. His silent demeanor speaks volumes and allows the player to constantly question what is on his mind. We never really know for sure. He is also a humble reminder that one person, one man, can be enough to make a difference in the world. In a way, Gordon Freeman, is us or at the least a reflection. Of what could happen at any given moment when we least expect, it. Would we rise to be the hero? Again, this is a masterful game with a wonderful main character. A transition, from average person to Hero of the moment and eventually of the world, a man who continues his fight for survival against overwhelming odds, regardless of what comes before him, the ability to take responsiblity for one's own actions, etc. There are so very many motifs and without Half-Life, gaming wouldn't be where it is, today. Before Half-Life, most first person shooters of the time were just run and gun and find the way out of the maze of the level. Half-Life threw that concept out and set a new level for future FPS's to meet.  Set in the Black Mesa underground research facility in the New Mexico desert the player takes the role of Dr. Gordon Freeman, a MIT graduate in theoretical physics, who is helping do research on teleportation but one experiment goes wrong and opens a portal to another planet whose inhabitants attack and try taking over the facility. All the while, Gordon Freeman’s goal is close the portal and escape alive.  Gameplay is standard fair for a FPS, the player has weapons to shoot and gains a better arsenal as the game progresses. But what set Half-Life apart from all the other games of the time was that Half-Life integrated a thorough storyline that unfolded just as if the player was actually there. The graphics look blocky by today's standards but was a graphical powerhouse back in 1998 with clear faces of the NPC’s and moving mouths during dialogue all in real time with the game’s engine. Sound in the game is sparse to convey the idea that the player is stuck in a underground facility but some music is heard during boss or major actions scenes and are quite memorable because of the situations.  In the end Half-Life was a major release that no one saw coming and changed the way other FPS’s, and some other game genres, were made and told stories.  9/10

Disclaimer: This is an opinionated review, so some of my opinion might show occaisionally, whether you agree or not is up to you, and I respect your opinion. It also contains mostly no spoilers except the final paragraph.  Half-Life 1 was a science-fiction FPS shooter first released in 1998 that revolutionized narriative in FPSs and Games in general. It was the story about a scientist named Gordon Freeman (our silent protagonist) escaping the Black Mesa after a dimension-colliding event known as the Ressonance Cascade brings forth several hostile creatures from Xen.   What do I think of it? Well for starters here's the pros and cons  Pros: Great use of combining narriative with gameplay and immersion, story is great, gameplay is awesome, weapon and skill progression is well-implemented, boss fights are fun (with the exception of Gargantuas and the tesla coil), level design is well-made and memorable, good shooting mechanics and controls, shift-jump is awesome, upgrading to a new weapon feels rewarding and gives a sense of progression, the chapter names sound awesome (maybe that's just me).  Cons: Platforming is outdated and the controls for it are incredibly slippery, some levels can seem unfair, a few minor glitches (like a glarring one in Aprehension wherein Gordon can be stuck in a black room after the cutscene when the soldiers drag him through the hallway), HD Models is the default and turning it off still has a few things of the original game that are missing/modified, hit-box issues with headcrabs for melee, tons of frustration.  Despite the amount of cons, the pros manage to outweigh them (at least in my opinion), Half-Life 1 was a revolutionary step for first-person shooters and narriative and honestly, I wish there were more games like Half-Life, especially in it's setting, plot, level-design and progression in general (not in it's platforming though).  Another con I forgot to mention (I left this last since it's incredibly opinionated), when I finished the game, I felt a sense of nostalgia, a sense of acomplishment, a sense of everything coming to fruition. Sure I was enjoyed the journey, but I wanted to see Gordon back home, and seeing him be locked by The G-Man himself made me go play Half-Life 2 to see what would happen. This would normally be a pro but then when I finished that game I ended up playing through the rest of the episodes to see what would happen, then I finally got to that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ cliff-hanger. And now everyday, I await for a Half-Life 3, so we can finally see Gordon reach the goal he wanted to reach ever since the first game, to finally go back home and for everything to go back to normal.   In all honestly, I recommend it, but if those cons or anything I mention is something that you wouldn't enjoy, then it's up to you whether to pick up the game or not.

One of the few near flawless games ever made, Half Life admitedly does have some frustrating and rather dated niggles, which I'll bring up before anything else. The platforming is actually quite bad. It never works that well in first person unless climbing mechanics are made entirely contextual. In Half Life, of course, nothing is contextual and you are in complete control of Freeman at all times. When the numerous platforming sections come around, though, the game feels extremely sensitive and you are expected to jump and land onto some really ridiculously narrow platforms to progress. It becomes a real exercise in frustration, and trial and error is often the only way of knowing whether or not Freeman will land on the platform or fall right to his doom. I guess the creation of such an impressive physics engine means that the developers will make it their civic duty to show it off as much of it as feasible in the game. It's just that Valve took a little too much liberty in showing it off in Half Life.   As I've said before, Half Life is a near flawless game, let down only by it's jumping sections. Ignoring those, and you should, this is one of the very best FPSs ever made, possibly THE greatest FPS game ever made. It's ridiculously good. The worldbuilding is astonishingly lifelike, the aliens quirky and instantly iconic thanks to their imaginative designs, the weapon selection is marvellous and transformed the straightforward crowbar into a symbol of gaming culture and the story is one of the strongest in gaming. Seriously, the feeling of being part of a grand conspiracy far greater than your own understanding, together with being the unwitting hero tasked to save the world from an alien invasion and travelling through the chaos happening all around you makes for a rip-roaring roller coaster of a game that never gets boring or repetitive, well, ever really.   Gunplay is appropriately meaty and cathartic, yet with an added sense of realism that you didn't find with other FPS classics like Quake and Doom. I rate this game better than Half Life 2, on the grounds that the gameplay is just as good but the story can be treated as one holistic story rather than the mere beginnings of a grander story planned to be told in something like, say, erm a TRILOGY. Yeah it basically boils down to Half Life 1 not ending on a cliffhanger which will likely never be resolved, as it's sequel did.   So yeah, buy Half Life if you haven't already, experience one of the few games that can truly be called a 'Citizen Kane of Gaming' and don't read THAT much into the greater plot going on. That way, you can feel wholly satisfied with everything this amazing game offers and not go mad waiting for the final chapter to be released sometime in the next 3000 years.  9.5/10

Wowza. Half Life, woah. Well, back in the day, Half Life was the start of something new in FPS's. What that is, exactly, cannot be put into a simple sentence, it's even difficult desribing it in a whole review!  Some of the features you get with Half Life: Fluent controls with fun action and much more.  The story of Half Life is very interesting. You see, you are a scientist that works for Black Mesa (a scientific research lab for a bunch of cool stuff), during a certain test with a portal thing, all Hell breaks loose. There are aliens EVERYWHERE, scientists and security guards are dying, and, to make matters worse, some marines that are coming to '''save''' you come down to the labs. I mean, all of this stuff is going on, and you just want to leave. Gordon Freeman (the player) doesn't speak, nobody knows why, but he doesn't.  The gameplay in Half Life is extremely fun and action packed; even by today's standards. I'd say it's better than some of our FPS games today! You can pick up health and charge up your HEV suit, a suit designed for specific tests that go on in Black Mesa. A fully charged suit can make you survive a LOT longer then with just health, as health easily drains without suit power.  You have a very wide selection of weapons in Half Life; from a crowbar to experimental energy weapons. Each weapon has their own unique use. For example: The crowbar is useful for killing weak enemies such as headcrabs and wounded enemies, it can also be used to easily open crates. Some weapons are better for close range (shotgun, assault rifle?, and crowbar), and some for far range (revolver, that one energy rifle thing, crossbow, Ghostbuster gun).  The enemies in Half Life are actually pretty challenging to fight, the marines specializing in ranged combat and explosives and the aliens with melee and more energy attacks. Some enemies, such as the headcrab, are very easy to kill, but are found in larger numbers.  Music the music in Half Life is pretty good, but there is no constant music, which is pretty nice.  Online multiplayer, yeah, that's right, online multiplayer. Well, asside from the troubles of finding a server, the multiplayer is pretty fun and I actually kind of love it. So fun. But the only problem is that barely anyone plays on Half Life servers, they're playing their newly-fangled TF2 and CS:GO, whatever those are. This Game really stands up to its reputation. The graphics are actually really good considering its age and the story and gameplay are simply on point. I highly recommend to play this game on Hard difficulty in order to get the best experience out of it. Playing on Normal Mode was fun but I felt more like an unbeatable super trained veteran marine than like a scientist just trying to survive a catastrophic scenario he accidentaly got thrown into. However, on Hard the Gaming experience changes a lot (positively): - you are very short on ammunition making you think twice weather you simply try to rambo everything with your guns or if you take the (really lethal) risk of trying to kill stuff with your crowbar or if you actually try to sneak past certain enemies - Aliens and Enemies in general HURT (they really do). This actually made me get scared of those Aliens. They might not (considering today's graphics standards) look scary as a 3D-Model but if they are actually able to kill you with ease you start to feel true fear if they suddenly pop up behind a corner you just walked by. - Your playstyle becomes a lot more stealthy and thoughtful. This is actually really realistic. I mean how should a scientist with no combat experience and conditioning apart from maybe having watched the Star Wars Series take out a huge Unit of special Forces together with a bunch of invading aliens if he doesn't try to outsmart and surprise them ? These and some other experiences I gathered are really reasons to play this game on Hard difficulty. I was actually so surprised about how much better the Game felt on Hard that I decided to play all my future games on hard difficulty without beating it on any lower difficulty anymore.  As a result to my 30 hours journey into Half Life 1 I have to state that this is an awesome part of gaming history that everyone who calls himself a gamer should have played.
